Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated

Astronomical Events.title: Mercury at Greatest Western Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: Mercury reaches greatest western elongation of 27.3 degrees from the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Mercury since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the morning sky

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: March Equinox
Astronomical Events.desc: The Sun will shine directly on the equator and there will be nearly equal amounts of day and night throughout the world
Astronomical Events.misc: This is also the first day of spring (vernal equinox) in the Northern Hemisphere and the first day of fall (autumnal equinox) in the Southern Hemisphere.

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Worm Moon because this was the time of year when the ground would begin to soften and the earthworms would reappear

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Lyrids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Lyrids is an average shower, usually producing about 20 meteors per hour at its peak.
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by dust particles left behind by comet C/1861 G1 Thatcher, which was discovered in 1861

Astronomical Events.title: Supermoon (Full Moon)
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be near its closest approach to the Earth and may look slightly larger and brighter than usual.
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Pink Moon because it marked the appearance of the moss pink, or wild ground phlox, which is one of the first spring flowers

Astronomical Events.title: Eta Aquarids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Eta Aquarids is an above average shower, capable of producing up to 60 meteors per hour at its peak.
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by dust particles left behind by comet Halley, which has been observed since ancient times.

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Mercury at Greatest Eastern Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: The planet Mercury reaches greatest eastern elongation of 22 degrees from the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Mercury since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the evening sky. Look for the planet low in the western sky just after sunset

Astronomical Events.title: Supermoon (Full Moon)
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be near its closest approach to the Earth and may look slightly larger and brighter than usual.
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Flower Moon because this was the time of year when spring flowers appeared in abundance.

Astronomical Events.title: Total Lunar Eclipse
Astronomical Events.desc: A total lunar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes completely through the Earth's dark shadow, or umbra. During this type of eclipse, the Moon will gradually get darker and then take on a rusty or blood red color
Astronomical Events.misc: The eclipse will be visible throughout the Pacific Ocean and parts of eastern Asia, Japan, Australia, and western North America.

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Annular Solar Eclipse
Astronomical Events.desc: An annular solar eclipse occurs when the Moon is too far away from the Earth to completely cover the Sun. This results in a ring of light around the darkened Moon
Astronomical Events.misc: Viewing Regions will be Russia, the Arctic Ocean, western Greenland, and Canada

Astronomical Events.title: June Solistice
Astronomical Events.desc: The North Pole of the earth will be tilted toward the Sun, which will have reached its northernmost position in the sky and will be directly over the Tropic of Cancer at 23.44 degrees north latitude
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the first day of summer (summer solstice) in the Northern Hemisphere and the first day of winter (winter solstice) in the Southern Hemisphere

Astronomical Events.title: Supermoon (Full Moon)
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be near its closest approach to the Earth and may look slightly larger and brighter than usual.
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Strawberry Moon because it signaled the time of year to gather ripening fruit. It also coincides with the peak of the strawberry harvesting season.

Astronomical Events.title: Mercury at Greatest Western Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: The planet Mercury reaches greatest western elongation of 21.6 degrees from the Sun.
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Mercury since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the morning sky. Look for the planet low in the eastern sky just before sunrise.

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Buck Moon because the male buck deer would begin to grow their new antlers at this time of year

Astronomical Events.title: Delta Aquarids Meteor Showe
Astronomical Events.desc: The Delta Aquarids is an average shower that can produce up to 20 meteors per hour at its peak
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by debris left behind by comets Marsden and Kracht

Astronomical Events.title: Saturn at Opposition
Astronomical Events.desc: The ringed planet will be at its closest approach to Earth and its face will be fully illuminated by the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: his is the best time to view and photograph Saturn and its moons

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Perseids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Perseids is one of the best meteor showers to observe, producing up to 60 meteors per hour at its peak
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by comet Swift-Tuttle, which was discovered in 1862

Astronomical Events.title: Jupiter at Opposition
Astronomical Events.desc: The giant planet will be at its closest approach to Earth and its face will be fully illuminated by the Sun. It will be brighter than any other time of the year and will be visible all night long
Astronomical Events.misc: A good pair of binoculars should allow you to see Jupiter's four largest moons, appearing as bright dots on either side of the planet

Astronomical Events.title: Blue Moon (Full Moon)
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Sturgeon Moon because the large sturgeon fish of the Great Lakes and other major lakes were more easily caught at this time of year

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Neptune at Opposition
Astronomical Events.desc: The blue giant planet will be at its closest approach to Earth and its face will be fully illuminated by the Sun. It will be brighter than any other time of the year and will be visible all night long
Astronomical Events.misc: Due to its extreme distance from Earth, it will only appear as a tiny blue dot in all but the most powerful telescopes

Astronomical Events.title: Mercury at Greatest Eastern Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: The planet Mercury reaches greatest eastern elongation of 26.8 degrees from the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Mercury since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the evening sky. Look for the planet low in the western sky just after sunset

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Corn Moon because the corn is harvested around this time of year

Astronomical Events.title: September Equinox
Astronomical Events.desc: The Sun will shine directly on the equator and there will be nearly equal amounts of day and night throughout the world
Astronomical Events.misc: This is also the first day of fall (autumnal equinox) in the Northern Hemisphere and the first day of spring (vernal equinox) in the Southern Hemisphere.

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Draconids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Draconids is a minor meteor shower producing only about 10 meteors per hour.
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet 21P Giacobini-Zinner, which was first discovered in 1900.

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Hunters Moon because at this time of year the leaves are falling and the game is fat and ready to hunt

Astronomical Events.title: Orionids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Orionids is an average shower producing up to 20 meteors per hour at its peak
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Halley, which has been known and observed since ancient times

Astronomical Events.title: Mercury at Greatest Western Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: Mercury reaches greatest western elongation of 18.4 degrees from the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Mercury since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the morning sky

Astronomical Events.title: Venus at Greatest Eastern Elongation
Astronomical Events.desc: The planet Venus reaches greatest eastern elongation of 47 degrees from the Sun
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Venus since it will be at its highest point above the horizon in the evening sky

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Taurids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Taurids is a long-running minor meteor shower producing only about 5-10 meteors per hour. It is unusual in that it consists of two separate streams
Astronomical Events.misc: The first is produced by dust grains left behind by Asteroid 2004 TG10. The second stream is produced by debris left behind by Comet 2P Encke

Astronomical Events.title: Uranus at Opposition
Astronomical Events.desc: he blue-green planet will be at its closest approach to Earth and its face will be fully illuminated by the Sun. It will be brighter than any other time of the year and will be visible all night long
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time to view Uranus. Due to its distance, it will only appear as a tiny blue-green dot

Astronomical Events.title: Leonids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Leonids is an average shower, producing up to 15 meteors per hour at its peak. This shower is unique in that it has a cyclonic peak about every 33 years where hundreds of meteors per hour can be seen. That last of these occurred in 2001
Astronomical Events.misc: The Leonids is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Tempel-Tuttle, which was discovered in 1865

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Beaver Moon because this was the time of year to set the beaver traps before the swamps and rivers froze

Astronomical Events.title: Partial Lunar Eclipse
Astronomical Events.desc: A partial lunar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes through the Earth's partial shadow, or penumbra, and only a portion of it passes through the darkest shadow, or umbra. During this type of eclipse a part of the Moon will darken as it moves through the Earth's shadow
Astronomical Events.misc: The eclipse will be visible throughout most of eastern Russia, Japan, the Pacific Ocean, North America, Mexico, Central America, and parts of western South America

Astronomical Events.title: New Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will located on the same side of the Earth as the Sun and will not be visible in the night sky
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the best time of the month to observe faint objects such as galaxies and star clusters because there is no moonlight to interfere

Astronomical Events.title: Total Solar Eclipse
Astronomical Events.desc: A total solar eclipse occurs when the moon completely blocks the Sun, revealing the Sun's beautiful outer atmosphere known as the corona
Astronomical Events.misc: The path of totality will for this eclipse will be limited to Antarctica and the southern Atlantic Ocean

Astronomical Events.title: Geminids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Geminids is the king of the meteor showers. It is considered by many to be the best shower in the heavens, producing up to 120 multicolored meteors per hour at its peak
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by debris left behind by an asteroid known as 3200 Phaethon, which was discovered in 1982

Astronomical Events.title: Full Moon
Astronomical Events.desc: The Moon will be located on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun and its face will be will be fully illuminated
Astronomical Events.misc: This full moon was known by early Native American tribes as the Cold Moon because this is the time of year when the cold winter air settles in and the nights become long and dark

Astronomical Events.title: December Solstice
Astronomical Events.desc: The South Pole of the earth will be tilted toward the Sun, which will have reached its southernmost position in the sky and will be directly over the Tropic of Capricorn at 23.44 degrees south latitude
Astronomical Events.misc: This is the first day of winter (winter solstice) in the Northern Hemisphere and the first day of summer (summer solstice) in the Southern Hemisphere

Astronomical Events.title: Ursids Meteor Shower
Astronomical Events.desc: The Ursids is a minor meteor shower producing about 5-10 meteors per hour
Astronomical Events.misc: It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Tuttle, which was first discovered in 1790
